sub_title: Professor of Public Policy & Digitalisation at Leiden University
summary:
I am a full professor of Public Administration with a focus on digitisation and public policy at the Faculty of Governance and Global Affairs, Leiden University (The Hague Campus). I have a multidisciplinary background in IT and Policy sciences and my work is on the interface between digitalisation and government. How digital innovations challenge established practices and institutions of public governance and how these innovations can be used to support good and effective governance, is the core of my research. Current research include several projects on the politics and use of big data and algorithms in a public governance context. My research is multidisciplinary with teams comprising of policy and governance scholars alongside computer scientists, AI-experts and philosophers.

Specialties and research interests: digital governance, collaborative digital governance, AI, GovTech, algorithmic governance, public policy, digital platforms and infrastructures, public sector innovation, cybersecurity governance, big data, public-private collaboration.

school.name: Avans Hogeschool (Avans University of Applied Sciences)

projects.title: CORE
projects.description:
CORE will demonstrate how a powerful and innovative Consistently Optimised REsilient ecosystem implementation, integrating interoperability, security, resilience and real-time optimisation can produce cost effective, fast and robust solutions that will guarantee the efficient and secure transit of goods through the worldwide Global Supply Chain system. 

CORE will show how protecting and securing the Global Supply Chain, and reducing its vulnerability to disruption (whether caused by natural disasters, terrorism or other forms of undesirable or illegal activity), can be done while guaranteeing the promotion of a timely and efficient flow of legitimate commerce through the EuropeanUnion (EU) and other nations around the world. CORE will demonstrate that this can be done while at the same time offering tangible benefits to involved stakeholders (transaction, transport, regulatory and financial operators), thus facilitating its adoption by commercial entities.

projects.title: Governing public-private information infrastructures: a sociotechnical inquiry into tools of governance and factors impacting their adoption
projects.description:
Public-private information infrastructures (PPII) are used for exchanging information between public and private organisations, both business-to-business and business-to-government.  They can greatly support and enhance cooperation between organisations, compliance and government supervision. PPII consist of components owned, operated and maintained by various organisations; public and private.  However, there is no central control and existing governance arrangements are not necessarily applicable. Hence, governing PPII is a huge challenge and the tools used for the governance of PPII need to be acceptable for all key stakeholders, given the collaborative setting. 

In my VENI research, I combine insights from the field of interorganisational systems with literature on governance and public-private collaboration. I aim to find tools of governance that can be used in PPII and assess their applicability based on factors specific to the field of interorganisational systems. I will study multiple case studies in the domain of international trade, where multiple initiatives are undertaken to develop and adopt public-private information infrastructures. A survey will validate the outcomes to assess that the governance arrangements are acceptable to the key players involved.

contributors.headline: Professor of Public Policy & Digitalisation at Leiden University

projects.title: Cassandra: Common Assessment and analysis of risk in global supply chains
projects.description: The CASSANDRA project aims to make container security more efficient and effective. The project addresses the visibility needs of both business and government in the international flow of containerised cargo by developing a data sharing concept that allows an extended assessment of risks by both business and government. The CASSANDRA concept will improve supply chain visibility, efficiency of trade compliance and effectiveness of border control and supervision by combining E-Freight and E-Customs. I am part of various work-packages, such as requirements, business concept, impact assessment and business case development.

projects.title: Extended Single Window (ESW)
projects.description: When a vessel sails into the port of Rotterdam, information has to be submitted and collected in countless places. This project wants to bring all the actions together in a single point of contact with a coordinated and integrated border management system for seaports and airports. Parties of multiple supply chains - shippers, transporters, carriers and terminals - retrieve information from the same system. This system is completely connected to all the procedures for reliable and cost-effective chains. This streamlines customs, fiscal processes and physical movement of the loads. This streamlining offers a main port a competitive advantage, because it is quicker, easier, better and cheaper.

projects.title: Alliance for Vital Governance
projects.description:
Board member (secretary) of the Dutch Alliance for Vital Governance (Alliantie Vitaal Bestuur - AVB), a strategic research alliance for collaboration and knowledge transfer between government organizations and research institutes in the Netherlands. The focus is on the overlap between information- and communication technology, innovation and the public sector.

The Alliance includes the Dutch ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations, the ministry of Economic Affairs, the Dutch Tax and Customs Administration, the universities of Twente, Rotterdam, Utrecht, Tilburg and Delft and the research institutes TNO, Rathenau Instituut and Telematica Instituut.

contributors.headline: Professor of Public Policy & Digitalisation at Leiden University

projects.title: Kanalen in Balans (Channels in Balance)
projects.description: The ‘Kanalen in Balans’- project (‘Channels in balance’) was a combined research initiative with partners from government and academia, comprising the Dutch Ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations, the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs, SVB, UWV, IB-Groep, IND,VDP, Novay, the University of Twente, and Delft University of Technology. The project aimed to find solutions for the multichannel management problems of governmental organizations. In particular the project addressed channel synchronization and channel control.

contributors.headline: Professor of Public Policy & Digitalisation at Leiden University

projects.title: B-dossier
projects.description: A combined research initiative by the Telematica Instituut with partners from government and academia, including the Dutch Tax and Customs Administration, the Municipality of The Hague, SVB, UWV, ING,  ICTU, the University of Twente, and Delft University of Technology. The project aimed to support integrated, demand-driven electronic services from public and private organizations to citizens and businesses.

profile_positions.company: Leiden University - Faculty of Governance and Global Affairs
profile_positions.description:
Chair Public Administration, with a special focus on Digitalisation and Public Policy.
Head of The Hague Centre for Digital Governance.
profile_positions.title: Professor of Public Policy & Digitalisation

profile_positions.description: My research is about how digital innovations challenge the incumbent practices and institutions of public governance, and how these innovations might be used for innovations in (collaborative) governance
profile_positions.title: Associate Professor of Digital Governance

profile_positions.description:
Chair of the section Organisation & Governance, comprising approx. 50 people. 
The section studies governance and processes of decision-making in socio-technical systems, at the interface of technology and society. The group hosts multiple chairs and is part of the Multi-Actor Systems Department at the Faculty of Technology, Policy and Management at Delft University of Technology.
profile_positions.title: Head of Section Organisation & Governance

profile_positions.description:
Assistant professor (tenured, 2013) in the Policy, Organisation, Law and Gaming (POLG) group, part of the Multi-Actor Systems department of the Faculty of Technology, Policy and Management at Delft University of Technology.

Previously, I worked in the ICT group at the same faculty. There, I worked on information infrastructures in networks of government authorities and commercial parties in global supply chains. I was overall coordinator of the Living Labs and a member of the scientific coordination team in the EC FP7 project CASSANDRA.
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor
Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description:
PhD researcher and research fellow at Delft University of Technology at the faculty of Technology, Policy and Management. My (PhD) research project focused on coordination arrangements for public-private service networks and the (inter-) organizational innovations and issues in (e-) government service delivery to citizens and businesses. I worked on several projects with partners from government, business and academia.

Also, I was involved in teaching in both the Bachelor and Master programs of the faculty.
profile_positions.title: PhD Research Fellow

profile_positions.description:
Board member (secretary) of the Dutch Alliance for Vital Governance (Alliantie Vitaal Bestuur - AVB), a strategic research alliance for collaboration and knowledge transfer between government organizations and research institutes in the Netherlands. The focus is on the overlap between information- and communication technology, innovation and the public sector.

The Alliance includes the Dutch ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations, the ministry of Economic Affairs, the Dutch Tax and Customs Administration, the universities of Twente, Rotterdam, Utrecht, Tilburg and Delft and the research institutes TNO, Rathenau Instituut and Telematica Instituut.
